document.masterDocTitle: A review of the Cetoniinae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) from Argentina and adjacent countries: systematics and geographic distributions

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution:
ARGENTINA
( Schürhoff 1937 ; Blackwelder 1944 ):
Catamarca
: near the city ( Burmeister 1866 );
Tucumán
( Hayward 1942 , 1960 );
Santiago del Estero
: near Santiago del Estero (city), in the way to Tucumán ( Burmeister 1861 ); “ Chaco de Santiago ”, Col. Bourgoin [MNHN] ( Bourgoin 1912 );
“Chaco de Santiago” ( Bruch 1915 ), = Chaco ( Blackwelder 1944 ); “Muséum Paris / Chaco de Santiago del Estero / bord du Rio Salado / Env. d’Icaño / E.R. Wagner 1904”, “Type” [red label, printed], “
Gymnetis
/
Bouvieri Bourgoin
”, “

bouvieri

Gymnetis
/
bouvieri
/ Bourgoin / Ph. Antoine des. 2000” [inside a red frame
];
Same locality, 1 male paralectotype [MNHN]
,
1 male paralectotype [MNHN]
,
5 males paralectotypes , 2 females paralectotypes [BMNH]
( Antoine 2001 );
Chaco
: Pozo La Gringa
( Antoine 2001 );
La Rioja
: Chepes
( Viana & Williner 1981 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 30–37. General aspects of Gymnetini from Argentina: 30–31,
Gymnetis bouvieri
(30, Catamarca; 31, Santiago del Estero); 32,
Gymnetis carbo
(Chaco); 33–35,
Gymnetis cordobana
(33, male; 34, female; 35, female, ventral view); 36–37,
Gymnetis flavomarginata
(36, male; 37, female).

ARGENTINA
:
Misiones
: A. Breyer Collection , 2 exx. [ MACN ]
;
1 ex. [ MACN ], labeled “
Gymnetis
/
flavomarginata
/ Blanch. R.A.A.M. col.”;
1 ex. [ MACN ], labeled “
Gymnetis
/
flavomarginata
/ Blnch. / Dr. Dallas determ.”
.

Note 1 : Burmeister (1861 , 1943 ) mentions that he found “the
G. flavormarginata Bl. D’Orb.
from Corrientes in Santiago ” (translated from Spanish). This specimen belongs to
G. bouvieri
.

Note 2 : Burmeister (1861 , 1943 ) also mentioned that he found in Catamarca , “other similar (to
G. flavomarginata Blanchard, [1842]
) but different and smaller” (translated from Spanish). In 1866, Burmeister gave a brief description of this insect as a variety of
G. flavomarginata
: “a minor variety, instead of the eight big spots of pure yellow color, it has eight small orange spots, which are neither confluent nor prolongued in teeth” ( Fig. 30 ). The male genitalia of one of these specimens is identical to typical
G. bouvieri
from Santiago del Estero ( Fig. 38 ).

Note 3 : Lists of publications by Dallas were given by Pirán (1946 , 1954 ) and De Santis (1992) . Apparently
Gymnetis pudibunda var. minor
was not published. Therefore, the specimen at MLPA is not a type specimen.
Note 4 : In two specimens from La Rioja (Breyer Collection), the internal margin of the yellow elytral band is straight and parallel to the elytral margin.
Note 5 : Antoine (2001) mentioned six males from Pozo La Gringa ( Chaco ), comprising 1 ex. of the typical form, 3 exx. with reduced spots on the elytra, and 2 exx. without spots.
